They should embrace and uphold them with the four means of attraction, causing them to leave all evil and increase all good dharmas. With utmost sincerity, they should instruct them as if they were their only child;
They should not seek rewards, nor should they do it for fame, for material gain, or for their own happiness.

Next, one should teach the twelve divisions of the scriptures, meditative concentration, and the distinctions of profound meanings;
Regulating their body and mind, causing them to cultivate the six recollections and the Dharma of not being negligent;

Caring for the sick and suffering without giving rise to a weary mind, being able to endure harsh words, slander, and insults, and also being able to endure suffering that is added to the body and mind;

translated: Well knowing sharp faculties, middling faculties, and dull faculties, teaching dull-facultied people to give rise to faith, middling-facultied people able to make them pure and sincere, and sharp-facultied people causing them to attain liberation - if one can diligently teach in this way, it is called the meaning of a bodhisattva, it is called a good person, a lotus flower, a fragrant elephant among people, a well-tamed man, and called a great ship captain.
Good son!
It is better to receive evil precepts and in one day cut off the life roots of immeasurable beings, than to finally raise and keep evil disciples who cannot be disciplined.
Why is it so?
Good son!

This evil discipline brings misfortune to one's own body, and raising evil disciples who cannot be taught causes immeasurable beings to do evil, slanders immeasurable wonderful dharmas, destroys the harmonious Sangha, and causes many beings to commit the five heinous crimes. Therefore, it is worse than the sin of evil discipline.
Good son!
There are two kinds of bodhisattvas:
The first is lay, and the second is monastic.
Monastic bodhisattvas have two kinds of disciples:
The first is monastic, and the second is lay.
Lay bodhisattvas have one kind of disciple, namely lay disciples.
Monastic bodhisattvas teach monastic disciples the twelve divisions of the scriptures, and according to their offenses, instruct them in repentance.
They teach them the eight kinds of knowledge. What are the eight?

The first is the knowledge of dharmas, the second is the knowledge of meanings, the third is the knowledge of time, the fourth is the knowledge of contentment, the fifth is the knowledge of oneself, the sixth is the knowledge of the assembly, the seventh is the knowledge of faculties, and the eighth is the knowledge of discrimination.
Good man!

If bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are able to thus instruct and subdue their monastic disciples, both the teacher and the disciples will attain immeasurable benefits. In this way, the teacher and disciples can increase the Three Jewels.
Why is it so?

In this way, the disciple, having understood the eight knowledges, is able to diligently make offerings to teachers, elders, preceptors, and those with virtue, is able to accept good words, is able to diligently read and recite, and also gives the Dharma, with a mind free from negligence, taming sentient beings, is able to care for the sick and suffering, and provides for the poor and destitute.
Good sons!
If the renunciant bodhisattva has lay disciples, he should also first teach them the Dharma of non-negligence.
Non-negligence is precisely the practice of the Dharma;
making offerings to parents, teachers, preceptors, elders, and those with virtue, bestowing peace and happiness;
receiving precepts with utmost sincerity, not carelessly violating them;
not denying what has been entrusted;
being able to endure anger;
never engaging in harsh words, slander, or meaningless speech;
having compassion for sentient beings, always giving rise to a mind of respect and fear towards kings, elders, and ministers;
They are able to tame their own wives, children, and relatives, distinguish between enemies and friends, and do not slight sentient beings;
They remove arrogance and do not associate with bad friends;
They eat in moderation, eliminate greed, have few desires, and are content;
They do not go to places of dispute, and even in jest do not speak evil words. This is called the Dharma of being vigilant.
If a monastic bodhisattva keeps lay disciples, he should first teach them the Dharma of being vigilant.
When experiencing suffering or joy, they should always be together.
Even if they are in poverty and have needs, they should not be stingy with anything other than the six items.
When sick, they should seek what is needed for them, and when caring for the sick, they should not become weary.
If they do not have their own belongings, they should seek from the four directions;

If they are unable to obtain it by seeking, they should borrow from the Three Jewels. After recovering, they should repay it ten times according to worldly customs, according to the proper law of King Prasenajit's country.
If they are unable to repay, they should further be taught to say:
'You now owe much to the Three Jewels and are unable to repay it. You should diligently cultivate and attain the fruit of stream-entry up to the fruit of arhatship.

If you can wholeheartedly arouse the mind of enlightenment, or if you can teach a thousand people to give rise to pure faith in the Buddha's teachings, or if you can destroy a person's grave wrong views.'
The ordained bodhisattva who can teach the lay person such matters, both teacher and disciple, will both attain immeasurable benefits.
Good man!
If the lay bodhisattva keeps lay disciples, he should first teach them the Dharma of heedfulness.
The heedful one makes offerings to parents, teachers, preceptors, elders, and those with virtue;

He should also provide for his brothers, wife, children, friends, relatives, those who wish to travel, and those who have arrived from afar, as well as his servants and workers. He first provides them with food and drink, and then uses it himself;

Moreover, they should teach them to have faith in the Three Jewels, to share their suffering and joy, never to be partial or alone, to give rewards in a timely manner, to prevent hunger and cold, and never to beat, scold, whip, or torture them, but to speak softly and instruct them;
if there are sick ones, they should take care of them and seek what they lack.
They should teach them worldly matters, and when seeking marriage partners, they should not seek lowly ones;

they should teach them the five divisions of the scriptures of the TathÄgata. Seeing those who are separated and destroyed, they are able to reconcile them. After reconciling them, they cause them to increase their wholesome mind;
they should make offerings to all renunciant and non-Buddhist paths, without making distinctions - why is this?

First, by attracting them with giving, later they will be tamed. They should instruct them with the six ways of showing respect - if they seek wealth, they should engage in commerce, agriculture, or serve the king, always with a sincere mind and in accordance with the Dharma. Having obtained wealth, they should protect it in accordance with the Dharma;
Taking pleasure in merit and virtue, rejoicing when seeing others do so, this is called the Dharma of non-negligence.
If a lay bodhisattva can teach other lay bodhisattvas in this way, both the teacher and the disciple will attain immeasurable benefits.
Good man!
If a lay bodhisattva attains self-mastery and becomes a great king, he should protect the people as if they were his only child.
He should teach them to leave behind all evil and practice good deeds.
If he sees someone doing evil, he should beat and scold them, but never take their life.
He should take one-sixth of their wealth as tax.
If he sees someone angry and evil, he should teach them to cultivate patience and non-negligence.
His words should be gentle, and he should be able to distinguish between good and evil people. If he sees someone who has committed an offense, he should bear it and not ask about it.
He should always practice giving with whatever wealth he has.

He will read and recite the scriptures of the five divisions with all his might, and will be able to well protect his body, life, and property, and will be able to transform sentient beings so that they do not do evil.

Seeing those who are poor, he will give rise to great compassion, and will always cultivate contentment in his own country. He will never believe slanderous words from evil people, and will not seek wealth through unlawful means.
In accordance with the Dharma, he will protect the country and stay far away from seven kinds of evil:

First, he will not enjoy playing dice, chess, or backgammon; second, he will not enjoy hunting; third, he will not enjoy drinking alcohol; fourth, he will not enjoy lustful desires; fifth, he will not enjoy foul language; sixth, he will not enjoy divisive speech; seventh, he will not enjoy taking wealth through unlawful means.

They always enjoy making offerings to renunciant practitioners, causing the people of the country to always give rise to the thought of parents towards the king, believing in causes and effects, not giving rise to jealousy when seeing those who surpass themselves, not giving rise to arrogance when seeing those who are inferior to themselves, knowing to repay kindness, repaying even small kindnesses with great [acts of kindness],
being able to subdue the various faculties, purifying the three karmas,
praising good people, reprimanding evil people, speaking with a gentle voice first,
not having their own power and relying on others in accordance with the Dharma, not mobilizing the four armies when seizing other countries,
being able to rescue and liberate sentient beings in times of terror, always embracing them with the four means of attraction,
being able to skillfully distinguish various dharma characteristics, gently guiding those who do not accept the Dharma with soft words.
Good sons!
There are two kinds of bodhisattvas:
First, the lay bodhisattva; second, the renunciant bodhisattva.
It is not difficult for the renunciant bodhisattva to keep two kinds of disciples;
It is difficult for a lay bodhisattva to keep a single disciple.
Why is that?
Because lay people are often entangled in many evil conditions.

World-Honored One!
How can lay bodhisattvas receive the upÄsaka precepts?
Good man!
If lay bodhisattvas wish to uphold the upÄsaka precepts, they should first sequentially make offerings to the six directions:
The east, south, west, north, nadir, and zenith.

As for the east, it refers to one's parents. If a person can make offerings to their parents of clothing, food and drink, bedding, medicine, housing, wealth and treasures, and respectfully pay homage, praise, and revere them, then that person is able to make offerings to the east.
Parents will repay them with five things:
First, to love and care for them with utmost sincerity; second, never to deceive them; third, to give them wealth; fourth, to marry them to a noble family; fifth, to teach them worldly affairs.

As for the south, it refers to teachers and elders. If there are people who can offer clothing, food and drink, bedding, and medicine to teachers and elders, respect and praise them, make offerings and pay homage, get up early and go to bed late, and accept and practice good teachings, then these people will be able to make offerings to the south.
The teacher will also repay them with five things:

First, to teach quickly without losing time; second, to teach completely without leaving anything out; third, not to give rise to jealousy towards those who surpass oneself; fourth, to entrust them to strict teachers and good friends; fifth, to give them wealth at the time of death.

As for the West, it refers to one's wife and children. If a person can provide their wife and children with clothing, food, bedding, medicine, jewelry, and other adornments, then that person is making offerings to the West.
The wife and children will repay him with fourteen things:

First, doing everything with utmost care; second, always doing it without laziness; third, making sure to finish what is started; fourth, doing it quickly without missing the right time; fifth, always taking care of guests; sixth, keeping the rooms and bedding clean; seventh, loving and respecting him, speaking softly; eighth, instructing servants with gentle words; ninth, being good at guarding wealth and property; tenth, rising early and going to bed late; eleventh, being able to prepare clean food; twelfth, being able to endure instruction; thirteenth, being able to cover up bad things; fourteenth, being able to take care of the sick.

As for the north, it refers to good friends. If there are people who can make offerings to good friends, give to them according to their ability, respectfully and softly, pay homage and praise them, then this person will be able to make offerings to the north.
This good friend will also repay them with four things:

First, teaching them to cultivate good dharmas; second, causing them to leave evil dharmas; third, being able to rescue and liberate them when they are in fear; fourth, being able to cause them to abandon indulgence when they are lax.

As for the nadir, it refers to servants. If there are people who can provide servants with clothing, food and drink, and medicine for illness, and do not scold or beat them, then this person will be able to provide for the nadir.
Servants will also repay them with ten things:

First, not committing offenses; second, not waiting for instruction to act; third, ensuring completion of tasks; fourth, acting swiftly without missing the right time; fifth, not abandoning the master even in poverty; sixth, rising early; seventh, guarding possessions; eighth, repaying little with much; ninth, respectfully thinking of the master with sincerity; tenth, skillfully concealing the master's faults.

As for the upper direction, it refers to monks and brahmins. If one makes offerings of clothing, food and drink, dwellings, bedding, and medicine for illnesses to monks and brahmins, rescues them in times of danger, gives food in times of famine, stops them from doing evil when one hears of it, pays homage, respects, venerates, and praises them, then one is able to make offerings to the upper direction.
These renunciant people repay with five things:

First, teaching them to develop faith; second, teaching them to cultivate wisdom; third, teaching them to practice generosity; fourth, teaching them to uphold the precepts; fifth, teaching them to cultivate much learning.
If there are those who make offerings to these six directions, then these people will be able to increase their wealth and longevity and be able to uphold the precepts of an upÄsaka.
Good man!
If a person wishes to receive the precepts of an upÄsaka and increase their wealth and longevity, they should first consult their parents who gave birth to them.
If their parents agree, they should next inform their spouse, children, servants, and retainers;

If the ruler of the country agrees, then to whomsoever has left the household life and given rise to the mind of enlightenment, they should go to them, bow their head to their feet, ask about their well-being in soft words, and say thus:
'Venerable One!

'There are five things that people cannot increase their wealth and life by in the present.
What are the five?

'Good man!

If he says he can, he should be told again:
'Good man!

If he says he can, he should be told further:

How does one make offerings to the twelve divisions of the scriptures?

If one is able to wholeheartedly believe and enjoy, uphold, recite, explain, and practice as taught, and having done so for oneself, further encourages others to practice, this is called making offerings to the twelve divisions of the scriptures.
If one can copy the twelve divisions of the scriptures, and after copying them, make various offerings to them as if offering to the Buddha, except for bathing.
If there are those who make offerings, uphold, recite, and practice such a sutra, this is called making offerings to the Dharma.
When making offerings to the Dharma, it is like making offerings to the Buddha.

Moreover, there is another Dharma, namely, the one root of a bodhisattva, the three roots of a pratyekabuddha person, and the three truths. If one has faith in this, it is called making offerings to the Dharma.

If there are those who make offerings to those who have given rise to the bodhi mind, uphold the precepts, and have left the household life, and to those who are heading towards the state of a srota-Äpanna up to the state of an arhat, this is called making offerings to the Sangha.

If there are people who can make offerings in this way to the Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha Jewels, one should know that such a person will never be far from the TathÄgatas of the ten directions, and will always be with the Buddhas whether walking, standing, sitting, or lying down.
Good man!
If there are people who can make offerings to these three fields of merit according to the teachings, know that in immeasurable lives they will receive much benefit.
Good man!
There are two kinds of bodhisattvas:
First, the lay; second, the renunciant.
It is not difficult for the renunciant bodhisattva to make offerings to the Three Jewels;
Making offerings as a layperson is difficult.
Why is this?
Because laypeople are bound by many evil conditions.
